title: Unit 4 – Introduction to Trigonometry
subtitle: Jeopardy Review Game — Question Bank
notes: All LaTeX is written in plain text below for easy reading. The game file uses MathJax to render the notation.

questions.clue: Find the exact value of tan(π/4).
questions.notes: Unit circle at 45°: (√2/2, √2/2), so tan = y/x = 1.

questions.clue: Find the exact value of csc(7π/6).
questions.notes: 7π/6 is in Q III, reference angle π/6. sin(7π/6) = −1/2, so csc = −2.

questions.clue: Find the exact value of sec(5π/3).
questions.notes: 5π/3 is in Q IV, reference angle π/3. cos(5π/3) = 1/2, so sec = 2.

questions.clue: Find the exact value of cos(31π/6).
questions.notes: 31π/6 − 4π = 31π/6 − 24π/6 = 7π/6. Q III, reference angle π/6. cos(7π/6) = −√3/2.

questions.type: CHALLENGE (Jedi Master) — Inverse trig expressions + Angle Subtraction Formula
questions.clue: Evaluate without a calculator:  sin[ arccos(−1/2) − arctan(√3) ]
solution_steps: Step 1: arccos(−1/2) = 2π/3  (range [0, π], Q II).
Step 2: arctan(√3) = π/3  (range (−π/2, π/2), Q I).
Step 4: sin(π/3) = √3/2.

questions.clue: What is the reference angle for 315°?
questions.answer: 45°  (315° is in Q IV; reference angle = 360° − 315° = 45°)

questions.clue: Convert 5π/3 radians to degrees.
In which quadrant does the terminal side of −23π/10 lie?
solution_steps: Add 4π to get a positive coterminal angle: −23π/10 + 40π/10 = 17π/10.
17π/10 = 306°, which is between 270° and 360°, so it lies in Q IV.

questions.clue: Find one positive and one negative coterminal angle for θ = −25π/3. Express answers in radians.
solution_steps: Add 10π (5 full rotations): −25π/3 + 30π/3 = 5π/3  (positive coterminal).
Add 8π (4 full rotations):  −25π/3 + 24π/3 = −π/3  (negative coterminal).

questions.type: CHALLENGE — Stacking sign rules + coterminal angles + reference angles
questions.clue:
The angle θ satisfies BOTH: sin θ < 0 AND sec θ < 0.
(a) In which quadrant must θ terminate?
(b) If the reference angle is 2π/5, find all values of θ in [0, 4π].
questions.answer:
(a) Quadrant III.
(b) θ = π + 2π/5 = 7π/5  and  θ = 7π/5 + 2π = 17π/5.
solution_steps: sin θ < 0  →  Q III or Q IV.
sec θ < 0  means  cos θ < 0  →  Q II or Q III.
Intersection: Q III only.
Q III angle with ref 2π/5: θ = π + 2π/5 = 7π/5.
Add one full period: 7π/5 + 2π = 17π/5.

questions.clue: Find the exact value of arcsin(√3/2).
Find the exact value of arctan(−√3).
questions.notes: Range of arctan is (−π/2, π/2), so the answer is −π/3.

questions.clue: Find the exact value of arccos[sin(7π/6)].
solution_steps: Step 1: 7π/6 is in Q III with reference angle π/6, so sin(7π/6) = −1/2.
Step 2: arccos(−1/2) = 2π/3  (range [0, π], Q II).

questions.clue: Solve 2 sin x − 1 = 0 on [0, 2π].
choices: B) x = π/6 and x = 5π/6  ← CORRECT
questions.notes: sin x = 1/2. Sine is positive in Q I and Q II: x = π/6 and x = π − π/6 = 5π/6.

questions.type: CHALLENGE (Jedi Master) — Inverse trig expressions + Angle Addition Formula
questions.clue: Evaluate without a calculator:  cos[ arcsin(−√3/2) + arccos(−1/2) ]
solution_steps: Step 1: arcsin(−√3/2) = −π/3  (range [−π/2, π/2]).
Step 2: arccos(−1/2) = 2π/3  (range [0, π], Q II).
Step 4: cos(π/3) = 1/2.

questions.clue: State the vertical shift of:  f(x) = −3 sin(πx + 2) − 5
State the range of:  g(x) = 4 cos(x/2) + 3

Find the phase shift of:  y = 2 sin(2x − π/6) − 1
CAUTION: you must factor out the coefficient of x first.
questions.answer: Phase shift = π/12 to the RIGHT.
questions.notes: Factor: y = 2 sin(2(x − π/12)) − 1.  Common mistake: students say π/6 without dividing by b = 2.

questions.type: Graph + Multiple Choice — answers in factored form y = a·sin(b(x−c)) + d

graph_parameters.reflection: yes — graph goes DOWN from midline at left endpoint

graph_key_points: (π/4,  1)  — LEFT endpoint of period, midline, going DOWN  ← period starts here
(5π/4, 1)  — RIGHT endpoint of period, midline  ← period ends here
questions.clue: The graph of f is shown (plotted points mark both endpoints of one period). Which equation matches?
choices: A) y = 3 sin(2(x − π/4)) + 1      — NOT reflected (goes up first)
C) y = −3 sin(2(x + π/4)) + 1     — phase shift is LEFT, not right
D) y = −3 sin(2(x − π/4)) − 1     — midline at y=−1, not y=1

how_to_eliminate.A: At x=π/2 this gives +4 (max), but the graph shows −2 (min) there.
how_to_eliminate.C: Phase shift is left — the period would start at x=−π/4, not x=π/4.
how_to_eliminate.D: Midline = d = −1, but plotted points show midline y=1.

questions.type: CHALLENGE — Graph + Multiple Choice — answers in factored form y = a·cos(b(x−c)) + d
graph_key_points: (1,  3)  — LEFT endpoint of period, maximum  ← period starts here
(5,  3)  — RIGHT endpoint of period, maximum  ← period ends here
questions.clue: The graph of f is shown (plotted points at both period endpoints). Match the equation — written in y = a·cos(b(x−c)) + d form.
choices: B) y = 2 cos(π/2 · (x + 1)) + 1  — phase shift is LEFT (max at x=−1)
C) y = 2 cos(π/2 · (x − 1)) − 1  — midline at y=−1, not y=1
D) y = −2 cos(π/2 · (x − 1)) + 1 — reflected (starts at minimum, not max)

how_to_eliminate.B: At x=1 this gives 2cos(π)+1 = −1 (minimum), but graph shows maximum (y=3) there.
how_to_eliminate.C: Midline = d = −1; plotted points show midline y=1.
how_to_eliminate.D: At x=1 this gives −2cos(0)+1 = −1 (minimum), but graph shows maximum.

questions.clue: A Ferris wheel has a radius of 20 m and its center is 25 m above the ground. What are the maximum and minimum heights of a passenger?
A passenger's height (feet) on a Ferris wheel is modeled by  h(t) = 50 + 45 sin(πt/10),  where t is seconds. What is the period and what does it represent?
questions.answer: Period = 2π ÷ (π/10) = 20 seconds — the time for one complete revolution of the Ferris wheel.

questions.clue: A city's average monthly temperature follows a sinusoidal pattern with a maximum of 88°F and a minimum of 28°F. State the midline and the amplitude of the model.

Using h(t) = 50 + 45 sin(πt/10):
(a) At what time t does the passenger first reach maximum height?
(b) What is the minimum height?
questions.answer:
(a) sin(πt/10) = 1  →  πt/10 = π/2  →  t = 5 seconds.
(b) Minimum = 50 − 45 = 5 feet.

questions.type: CHALLENGE (Jedi Master) — Build model + Solve equation + Filter by direction
questions.clue:
A buoy bobs in the ocean. At t = 0 it is at its midpoint and moving UPWARD. Amplitude = 4 ft, period = 8 seconds.
(a) Write h(t) for the buoy's height above its midpoint.
(b) During the first 16 seconds, at what times is the buoy exactly 2 ft above the midpoint AND moving downward?
solution_steps: Model: starts at 0 moving up → sine.  b = 2π/8 = π/4.  So h(t) = 4 sin(πt/4).
Solve h(t) = 2:  sin(πt/4) = 1/2.
General solutions: πt/4 = π/6  →  t = 2/3  and  πt/4 = 5π/6  →  t = 10/3  (first cycle).
Second cycle (add 8): t = 2/3 + 8 = 26/3  and  t = 10/3 + 8 = 34/3.
Filter — MOVING DOWNWARD means past the maximum (t = 2 s).  t = 2/3 is BEFORE the max (moving up). t = 10/3 is after the max (moving down). ✓
Answer: t = 10/3 s and t = 34/3 s.

questions.clue: Convert 120 RPM to radians per second.
A wheel of radius 0.4 m spins at 5 rad/s. What is the linear speed of a point on its rim?
A bicycle wheel has a radius of 35 cm and rolls at 8 m/s. Find the angular speed in rad/s.

A satellite orbits Earth at radius 6800 km with a period of 90 minutes.
(a) Angular speed in rad/min.
(b) Linear speed in km/min.

questions.type: CHALLENGE (Jedi Master) — Gear train (3 parts, stacking v = ωr)
questions.clue:
A large gear (r = 18 cm) meshes with a small gear (r = 6 cm). The large gear turns at 40 RPM.
(a) Angular speed of large gear in rad/s.
(b) Angular speed of small gear in RPM.  (Meshing gears share linear speed at contact point.)
(c) A wheel of radius 4 cm is fixed to the small gear's axle. Linear speed of a point on its rim?
solution_steps: Convert large gear: 40 RPM × 2π/60 = 4π/3 rad/s.
Linear speed at contact: v = (4π/3)(0.18) = 0.24π m/s.
Small gear shares same linear contact speed: ω_small = v/r = 0.24π/0.06 = 4π rad/s.
Convert back to RPM: 4π × 60/(2π) = 120 RPM.
Wheel on small gear's axle — same ω as small gear: v = 4π × 0.04 = 0.16π ≈ 0.503 m/s.

final_jeopardy.clue:
A function f is periodic with period c, so f(t + c) = f(t) for all t. Which of the following are ALWAYS true? Justify each.
  I.  f(t − 2c) = f(t)
  II. f( (1/2)(t + c) ) = f( (1/2)t )
  III. f(t + 3c) = f(t)
  IV. f( (1/2)(t − 4c) ) = f( (1/2)t )
final_jeopardy.answer: TRUE: I, III, IV.   FALSE: II.
solution_steps: I.  f(t − 2c) = f((t − c) − c) = f(t − c) = f(t)  ✓  (apply period rule twice).
II. The argument (1/2)(t + c) differs from (1/2)t by c/2, which is NOT a full period. FALSE ✗.
III. f(t + 3c) = f(t + 2c) = f(t + c) = f(t)  ✓  (apply three times).
IV. Let g(t) = f(t/2). Then g has period 2c.  g(t − 4c) = f((t − 4c)/2) = f(t/2 − 2c) = f(t/2) = g(t)  ✓.
